PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The proposed Qingdao Huawei Windpower (QHW) Project is a grid connected renewable energy
project developed by Qingdao Huawei Wind Power Co. Ltd. The objective of the project is
electricity generation using state-of-the-art wind power generation technology and sale of the
electricity into the North China Power Grid (NCPG). The proposed project achieves CO emission 2
reduction by replacing electricity generated by fossil fuel fired power plant connected into the
NCPG.
For the proposed project, the scenario existing prior to the start of the implementation of the
project activity is NCPG providing the same electricity service as the proposed project. The
baseline scenario is the same as the scenario existing prior to the start of implementation of the
project activity.
The QHW Project consists of 12 wind turbine generators each with a capacity of 1300kW and 3
turbines each with 250 kW capacity. The total installed capacity is 16.35MW. The implementation
of the project was accomplished in November 2003.
For the calculation of the emission reductions of the project the production of one of the three 250
kW turbines has never been considered and also will not be part of the future VCS-QHW-Project.
This turbine was part of a pilot plant, that had been built in 2000, partly financed with a grant
provided by the German Ministry for Economic Development and Cooperation in a so called
Public-Private Partnership Program. Therefore the VCS-project consists of 14 wind turbines with
a capacity of 16.1 MW.
The annual electricity output estimation from 2014 onwards (20,757,555kwh) is calculated as the
average grid electricity output1 from 2009 to 2012 (Year 2009: 20,883,380kwh; Year 2010:
22,239,645kwh; Year 2011: 19,663,138kwh; Year 2012: 20,244,056kwh). The estimated annual
emission reductions are 19,034tCO e. 2
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
Sectoral Scope according to UNFCCC CDM Framework: Energy Industries - Electricity
Generation from Wind power. The project is not a grouped project.
1.3 Project Proponent
1 See monitoring reports and verification reports for year 2009 to 2012

1.12 Project Location
All areas included within the Project Area, and therefore all areas to undergo bamboo planting activities
are riparian buffer zones, under the state ownership of the Government of Rwanda, and under the
jurisdiction of the Rwanda Water Resources Board. Shape files used for the delineation of the riparian
buffer zones included within the project area are official government files.
Under the terms of the agreement between the project proponent and the Rwanda Water Resources
Board, the project location for the 500km of riparian buffer zones for the 2022 planting season was
provided in advance of validation. All areas are first assessed for eligibility, based off historical and
current landcover. Within such eligible areas, ground truthing is then required to define the exact planting
area, due to a range of aspects that may mean eligible areas are not suitable for planting. Such areas
include accessibility, where the likelihood of landslides is too high, where there is no suitable soil within
the riparian area for planting, or other aspects that can only be determined by the project’s team of GIS
technicians on the ground.
Following validation the 2022 proposed planting area was subsequently ground truthed and planted
during Q4 of 2022, during which the validation process has been ongoing.
As a result, the Project Area relating to the 500km of riparian plantings that occurred in 2022 are shown
below, and the associated KML file provided. The position of the first planting instance within Rwanda is
shown in Figure 5 below.
The 500km of riparian buffer zones to be planted during the 2023 planting season will be ground truthed
in advance of the Q4 2023 planting season and finalized during the land preparation process.

Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
The project area in the 1st project instance covers four districts, namely Ngororero, Karongi, Muhanga
and Ruhango. The total project area for the 1st planting instance represents 583.9km of rivers that are
categorized as “small” and therefore will only have a single line of planting on each bank. This 583.9km
project area is therefore greater than the total area to be planted (approximately 500km) allowing for non
plantable areas (such as rocky patches or areas where the river bank is too steep for planting) that can
only be determined during the planting season as the planting teams walk each river bank.
As such, the final project area and associated KML files are determined ex post, and this mapping
comprises an important part of project monitoring activities, as further detailed in Section 5 below.

Climatic Conditions
The annual average temperature is around 20°C. The annual rainfall averages 1,090 mm. The climate
is characterized by 4 seasons:
• The short rain season or Season A (mid-September – mid-January) considered as main planting
season.
• The short dry season with intermittent heavy rainfall (Mid-January to February) in which planting
may take place.
• The long rain season or Season B (March-May) where planting can occur until April.
• The long dry season with intermittent light rainfall (June – mid-September) where no planting

output: {'project_name': 'Rwanda Riparian Restoration Project', 'project_summary': 'The Rwanda Riparian Restoration Project is restoring riparian buffer zones in key watersheds and catchment areas within the mountainous areas of Rwanda. These buffer zones serve a critical ecological function as the interface between sensitive upland areas and the water resources that they buffer. The project is using select species of sympodial (clumping) bamboos. These planted bamboo clumps have an intricate underground root system that binds fragile soils and reduces erosion and loss of top soil from sloping agricultural lands. In addition this root system reduces siltation, protecting water resources for downstream users. The multi-dimensional bamboo canopy further serves to reduce the rate and volume of flow of rainfall into rivers reducing flooding, and protecting river banks. \r\n\r\nThe planted bamboo is purely for conservation and environmental purposes, while having high carbon emission removal benefits as a permanent and carbon rich ecosystem.', 'project_state_province': 'Karongi', 'project_country': 'Rwanda', 'project_latitude': -2.12, 'project_longitude': 29.62}

2.6 Methodology Deviations
There is no methodology deviation.
3 QUANTIFICATION OF GHG EMISSION REDUCTIONS AND REMOVALS
3.1 Baseline Emissions
As per the approved consolidated Methodology ACM0002 (Version 17.0, EB 89, Annex 1) para 44:
Baseline emissions include only CO emissions from electricity generation in fossil fuel fired power 2
plants that are displaced due to the project activity. The methodology assumes that all project
electricity generation above baseline levels would have been generated by existing grid-connected
power plants and the addition of new grid- connected power plants. The baseline emissions are to
be calculated as follows:
BE = EG x EF y PJ,y grid,CM,y
Where:
BE = Baseline emissions in year y (t CO /yr) y 2
EG = Quantity of net electricity generation that is produced and fed into the grid as a PJ,y
result of the implementation of the CDM project activity in year y (MWh/yr)
EF = Combined margin CO2 emission factor for grid connected power generation in grid,CM,y
year y calculated using the latest version of the “Tool to calculate the emission
factor for an electricity system” (t CO /MWh) 2
As per methodology, combined grid emission factor as per the “Tool to calculate the emission
factor for an electricity system” version 05 is calculated as below.
CO Baseline Database for the Indian Power Sector, Version 12, May 201739 published by Central 2
Electricity Authority (CEA), Government of India has been used for the calculation of emission
reduction.
As per Methodological tool: Tool to calculate the emission factor for an electricity system (Version
05.0, EB 87, Annex 9), following six steps have been followed:
(a) Step 1: Identify the relevant electricity systems;
(b) Step 2: Choose whether to include off-grid power plants in the project electricity system
(optional);
(c) Step 3: Select a method to determine the operating margin (OM);
(d) Step 4: Calculate the operating margin emission factor according to the selected method;
39 http://www.cea.nic.in/reports/others/thermal/tpece/cdm_co2/user_guide_ver12.pdf

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1.12.2 Emissions Trading Programs and Other Binding Limits
Not applicable.
1.12.3 Participation under Other GHG Programs
This is the first and only application for this project to a GHG program. Indicate whether the
project has been registered, or is seeking registration under any other GHG programs. Where the
project has been registered under any other GHG program, provide the registration number and
details.
1.12.4 Other Forms of Environmental Credit
No other environmental credit has been created by this project. The co-benefits of the project
have been proposed for validation to the Climate, Community, and Biodiversity Alliance using the
Climate, Community and Biodiversity Standard 2nd Edition. Gold level validation is expected
based on exceptional biodiversity benefits.
1.12.5 Projects Rejected by Other GHG Programs
This is the first and only application for this project to a GHG program.
1.13 Additional Information Relevant to the Project
Leakage Management
Leakage was determined using module “Estimation of emissions from activity shifting for avoided
planned deforestation (LK-ASP)”. Because this is a planned deforestation project and the agent
of deforestation is known, no deductions are taken for leakage. Monitoring of the landowners
property will occur as indicated in LK-ASP and M-MON.
Since leakage can only occur on property owned by the project proponent in Belize, the primary
leakage management strategy is to protect the rest of the property from conversion or fire
damage. The project proponent is expending considerable effort in fire prevention and
suppression (built and maintain a fire tower, on staff fire crew and equipment, prescribe fire and
thinning regime to reduce severity of fires) and has committed to not converting any land to

with the possibility to renew for an additional 30-year period.

1.11 Description of the Project Activity
Mangroves in the Southern Province of Sierra Leone (Bonthe and Moyamba districts) are disappearing at
a fast rate, driven by the unsustainable mangrove wood harvest for daily cooking, fish smoking, housing
construction, conversion to rice paddies or salt mines, and the expanding footprint of a growing
population. Furthermore, unsustainable fishing and shellfish collection practices, mainly by international
IUU trawlers, have diminished the fish stock, forcing local communities to harvest additional mangrove
wood to be sold as an alternative income. Throughout the project area, mangrove overexploitation and
deforestation have led to significant coastline erosion. Communities have tried to reinforce their
shorelines over the past 20 years to stop erosion while continuing to harvest mangroves, but failed to
stop soil loss (e.g., village in Sittia; Figure 1).
Figure 1. A village in the north of Sittia is seen via satellite in 2005 (left), 2014 (middle), and 2022 (right).

Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
Huojia County Second MSW Landfill Site LFG Pollution Treatment and Comprehensive
Utilization Project (hereafter referred to as the project) is located in Beizhuang Village, Xuying
Town, Huojia County, Xinxiang City, Henan Province, P.R. China. The project is constructed
and operated by Huojia County BCCY New Energy Co., Ltd. The objective is to collect the
landfill gas (LFG) from Huojia County Second MSW landfill site (hereafter referred to as
Huojia Second landfill site) and utilize it to generate electricity.
Huojia Second landfill site started collecting and handling waste in 2021 with a total design
effective capacity of 1,306,300 m3 and a municipal solid waste (MSW) disposal of 330 tons/d
and an operational lifespan of 10 years.
The project started to construct on 10/10/2021 and started operation on 27/12/2021.The
project has a total designed capacity 1MW (2*0.5MW) and combusts the LFG, which contains
nearly 50% of methane, to generate electricity and export it to the Central China Power Grid
(CCPG). The project collects and utilizes LFG from Huojia Second landfill site for power
generation, which would otherwise be released into the atmosphere. Methane in the LFG has
been emitted to the atmosphere since the landfill started operation. Therefore, the project
avoids methane emissions and, at the same time, electricity is generated from a renewable
energy source, instead of being provided by the grid. Total electricity supplied to the grid in
the crediting period will be 42,602 MWh. VCUs will be claimed from the methane destroyed
and the grid electricity displaced. The estimated average GHG emission reduction of the
project is 25,744 tCO e and the total GHG emission reductions and removals are 257,446 2
tCO e during the fixed 10 years crediting period. 2
Scenario existing prior to the implementation of the project (the same as baseline scenario):
LFG from Huojia Second landfill site is emitted to the atmosphere directly.
Equivalent electricity generated by the project is supplied by the Central China Power Grid
(CCPG), which is dominated by fossil fuel based power plants.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
Sector scope 1: energy industries (renewable /Non-renewable sources) and
Sector scope 13: waste handling and disposal.
The project is not a grouped project.

The environmental impact assessment (EIA) for this project was carried out by the Sichuan Investigation,
Design & Research Institute of Water Resources and Hydropower. The EIA report has already been
approved by Bureau of Environmental Protection of Sichuan Province on 3rd June, 2004.
In general the proposed project will bring about more positive environmental benefits than adverse
impacts. There are no significant sensitive environmental factors in the proposed project site. According
to the survey, there are no rare vegetation and endangered fauna in the proposed project site. According to
the monitoring, the water and air quality in Xi River are in good status. The noise in the barrage area
meets the national standards.
The EIA highlights the following environmental impacts. And where negative impacts of the proposed
project were identified, mitigation measures were suggested and defined.
(cid:122) Water
In construction phase the proposed project will produce several waste water streams mainly from
factory and living sewage. To prevent the waste water from factory contaminating Xi River, from
stone processing will be recycled after precipitation and flocculation; the waste water from concrete
stirring and washing will be recycled after precipitation and neutralization; the amount of oily waste
water will be limited due to the short application period and it will be treated regularly and
flocculated; the living sewage will be used for irrigation after processing. These measures are
practical and sufficient to prevent the pollution of Xi River.
(cid:122) Air
There will be some dust pollution from stone processing, blast and transportation. To minimize this
effect, measures to be adopted are as follow: to ban random digging and piling up of sand; to cover
the side to be blew up with straw bag; to cover vehicle loads and water spraying and etc.
(cid:122) Noise
Noise is mainly from blast in the place of dam and plant, machinery, stone processing factory, truck-
mixer and other auxiliary enterprises. Since the blast is instant and no night work is performed, only
very limited and temporary impacts are on the local people. As the two nearest villages situate
1.5Km upriver and downriver separately, when the noise spreads to the location of the villages, it has
met the <Standard of environmental noise of urban area> (GB3096-93) already.

including tussock (Festuca,Stipa), short grasses(Poa,Carex) and a variety of shrubs.
Interspersed throughout the dominant steppe landscape are a small proportion of wet

Current and historical land-use:

ungulate herbivores, called Guanacos (Lamaguanicoe),alongside with aboriginal
hunter-gatherer peoples who performed migratory hunting of these animals. Guanaco
populations migrated seasonally, allowing the land to rest for long periods at a time,
promoting regrowth of grasses and other vegetation. In the late nineteenth century,
European settlers introduced domesticated grazing animals and established private
property, limiting aboriginal peoples’ opportunity for continuing migratory hunting.

It is expected ultimately to comprise >500,000 hectares and generate on average an estimated 620,000 of emissions reductions annually. Improved grazing will increase the rest and rotation on pastures above baseline practices and reduce unrestricted grazing by livestock. Pastures will be grazed with higher livestock densities followed by longer periods of rest, increasing both plant productivity and soil carbon inputs relative to baseline conditions. This results in the sequestration of greenhouse gases from the atmosphere to the soil. \r\nLand operators are provided funding to increase fencing and water access needed to create more and smaller pastures and to provide the added labor needed to manage more frequent livestock movements. Project participants are required to manage for concentrated animal impact on small pastures with a focus on extended rest periods allowing for regrowth and recovery of leaf tissue, seed establishment, and replenishment of root reserves. In the baseline scenario, the pastures are larger and the livestock movement among pastures is less frequent. This allows grazing animals to select for preferred perennial species, which then become overgrazed and insufficient rest periods favor the encroachment by shrubs, annual grasses, and larger occurrence of bare ground.\r\nThe grouped project is on eligible grasslands of Argentina. The project area consists of grassland grazed by livestock on participating farms. Soils throughout the project area are primarily coarse-textured sand to sandy loam and have been losing carbon for over 100 years due to the continuous, selective grazing under the baseline scenario. region.

grassland areas, however these are generally degraded and are not natural grasslands. Rather
they are the outcome of historical deforestation and forest degradation. The elephant grass

This analysis shows that the project activity faces barr iers that (a) prevent the implementation of this type 
of proposed project activity; and (b) do not pr event the implementation of the alternatives. 
 
Sub-step 3a. Identify barrie rs that would prevent the implementation of  the project type of the proposed 
project activity: 
 
1. Power generation projects using new renewable energy technologies face significant barriers in most 
countries. Many industrialised countries have esta blished financial support systems to encourage such 
environmentally friendly power generation. However, such support systems can be expensive and are not 
generally available in developing countries. 
 
While the government of China has supported renewa ble energy sources for more than a decade, the 
development of wind power projects has not been very  fast. Indeed, most of the wind projects in China do 
not receive satisfactory tariffs and are applying for CDM registration. 
 
Barriers are identified and assessed below. 
 
Investment barriers 
 
International development aid, e.g. from the World Bank, Asian Development Bank, and KfW, as well as 
government tariff support have been used in China since 1993 to encourage the development of the wind 
power industry in the country. However, in recent year s, the provisions of such soft loans and subsidised 
government interest rates have gra dually decreased, the windfarm developers now have to apply for more 
commercial loans, furthermore, for a windfarm project only with attractive financial expectation, can the 
commercial loan be obtained in time successfully. 
 
In China the approximate investment costs of the windfarm is about 8000-10000 RMB Yuan per kW, 
which is double that of the thermal plant, furtherm ore the utilization hours of windfarm are about from 
2000 to 2500 hours, which is about one third of that of the thermal plant. Besides the common worse 
finance condition than the thermal plant project, for the proposed project, to best suit the local wind 
resource, the 850kW turbine of Vestas (V52-850) was se lected by bidding, which is more expensive than 
other turbine per kW. The total investment cost per kW of the proposed project is 10,587 RMB Yuan, 
significantly higher than that of all thermal plants.  
 
All these factors above make the  financial  return  rate   of  the  investment  and  the  ability  of  loan 
repayment of the proposed project at a lower level. Without the help of CDM, the proposed project would 
face the difficulty in obtaining the commercial loan. Indeed, the potential revenue of selling CERs from 
the CDM project played an important role in the loan application and finally assisted in the decision of the 
Bank of Communications to take on the loan obligation. 
 
For the proposed project, additional CDM financing may enable the investment return to be competitive 
with other projects and also allow the company to mitigate foreign exchange risks associated with the 
purchase of equipment from abroad. Having a full realization of this, the developer of the Chifeng 
Saihanba East Windfarm Project started the CDM ap plication process aiming to obtain the additional 
funding to secure the project financially and institutionally.  
 
Tariff barriers  
 
A windfarm project is not the least cost option for capacity expansion in the Northeast Power Grid. There 
is an abundance of coal and considerable new co al-fired generation projects will be constructed,

1.8 Project Start Date
According to VCS standard, v4.3, the project start date is the date on which activities that lead to
the generation of GHG emission reductions or removals are implemented (e.g., preparing land
for seeding, planting, changing agricultural or forestry practices, rewetting, restoring hydrological
functions, or implementing management or protection plans). For this project, according to the
requirements of the AMS-III.AU methodology applied, an entire cropping season is started from
land preparation and the emission reduction calculation is also started on this day. So, the project
start date was on 02-May-2018 when the land preparation started.

combined total project crediting period of 21 years from 02-May-2018 to 01-May-2039, and the
first 7-year period is from 02-May-2018 to 01-May-2025. Also, the project lifetime2 is 30 years
from 15-April-20183 to 14-April-2048.

reservoirs were put into use on 15-April-2018. Therefore, the project lifetime starts on 15-April-2018 instead of

A.5. Public funding of project activity

The project is not utilizing any Official Development Assistance (ODA) and does not involve any public

A.6. Debundling for project activity
>>
According to section 8.2 of the Clean development project standard, version 5.0 and Guideline of
assessment of debundling of SSC project activities, ‘De-bundling’ is defined as ‘the fragmentation of a
large project activity into smaller parts’. A small scale project activity that is part of a large project
activity is not eligible to use the simplified modalities and procedures for small-scale CDM project
activities.
A small-scale project activity shall be deemed to be a de-bundled component of a large project activity if
there is a registered small-scale CDM project activity or an application to register another small-scale
CDM project activity:
(cid:1) With the same project participants;
(cid:1) In the same project category and technology/measure;
(cid:1) Registered within the last 2 years; and
(cid:1) Whose project boundary is within 1 km of the project boundary of the small- scale activity at the
closest point
The project activity meets the above stated criteria as no other project activity has been taken up by same
project proponent under the same project category or technology/measure within 1km of the project
boundary of the small scale activity at the closest point. Hence, the project activity is not a de-bundled

Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
Shenzhen Cypress Carbon Environmental Technology Service Co., Ltd. (hereinafter “Shenzhen

emission reduction project. As a consultant, Shenzhen Cypress is responsible for helping project
sponsors in the development and management of carbon projects, including preparing
monitoring plans, organizing training, etc.
1.8 Project Start Date
According to VCS standard, v4.3, the project start date is the date on which activities that lead to
the generation of GHG emission reductions or removals are implemented (e.g., preparing land
for seeding, planting, changing agricultural or forestry practices, rewetting, restoring hydrological
functions, or implementing management or protection plans). For this project, according to the
requirements of the AMS-III.AU methodology applied, an entire cropping season is started from
land preparation and the emission reduction calculation is also started on this day. So, the project
start date was on 03-May-2018 when the land preparation started.
1.9 Project Crediting Period
The crediting period of this project will be using a 7-year, twice renewable crediting period, for a
combined total project crediting period of 21 years from 03-May-2018 to 02-May-2039, and the
first 7-year period is from 03-May-2018 to 02-May-2025. Also, the project lifetime2 is 30 years
from 08-April-20183 to 07-April-2048.
1.10 Project Scale and Estimated GHG Emission Reductions or Removals
2 The Acceptance Report of Qianfeng Farm of Fuyuan City National Comprehensive Agricultural Development High-
standard Farmland Construction Project in 2017.

are put into use, while the start dates of the project and of the crediting period are the dates when the project
begins to produce emission reductions. According to the acceptance report of the project, the ditches and
reservoirs were put into use on 08-April-2018. Therefore, the project lifetime starts on 08-April-2018 instead of
the project crediting period start date on 03-May-2018.

Each Project Activity Instance will involve a single wind turbine or multiple wind turbines with a
total capacity less than or equal to 10 MW, and will be interconnected to the regional electricity
system grid which is served by a mix of fossil fuelled and non-fossil fuelled power plants. By
adding new wind-powered electric generation to this grid, a mix of other power plants will operate
less by the equivalent amount of generation produced by the wind turbines. The power plants
affected by new wind generation are mostly base loaded fossil fuelled power plants. Fossil
fuelled power plants release carbon dioxide emissions during their operation, and the addition of
new wind generation and the resultant displacement of generation from these and other power
plants will create net GHG emission reductions.
The Initial Project Activity Instance is located north of the Lake Region State College in Devils
Lake, North Dakota. The Project consists of a single wind turbine rated at 1.6 MW with an
expected operating life of 20 years. The project will be electrically interconnected to the Lake
Region State College campus electrical system, where available energy will be delivered to the
campus. Any net excess energy above and beyond the campus’ electrical demand will be sold to

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The project is developed in 7 native communities belonging to the Shipibo Conibo and Cacataibo
ethnicity, which grouped occupy an area of 127,004.0 hectares of forest. This communities are
politically located in the district of Irazola, Masisea, Calleria and Iparia in Padre Abad and Coronel
Portillo provinces in the department and region of Ucayali, and in the district of Codo de Pozuzo,
Puerto Inca and Tornavista in Puerto Inca province in the department and region of Huánuco.
The purpose of the project is to conserve the forests of these communities against the
deforestation and degradation advance. It is proposed to reduce the pressure to change the land
use in the project area with 4 components: proper use of communal land, capacity building for the
management of natural resources, project finance and market linkages and finally strategic
alliances. These actions are intended to prevent the advance of deforestation. To this will be
performed partnerships and permanent coordinations with institutions that currently are conducting
conservation activities in the area.
Also, the system control and monitoring of communities will be strengthened through the
establishment and operation of a community monitoring, representing a strategy of community
participation.
With these actions, the project hopes to avoid an annual average net emissions of 564,818.5 tCO - 2
e according to the reference scenario projected for the first 10 years.
The project includes benefits for the population involved as well as for the conservation of
biodiversity, beyond the benefits of reducing GHG emissions. The project has applied the
standards of Climate, Community & Biodiversity Association (CCBA).
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
Sectoral Scope 14 - Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use.
AFOLU project category: Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation (REDD+).
Type of activity: Avoiding Unplanned Deforestation and Degradation (AUDD)
1.3 Project Proponent
Under the framework of the RED-PD 033/11 Rev.3 (F) project "Enhancement of ecosystem
services in managed forests of 7 native communities in the Ucayali region", the PDD was
elaborated by Association for Research and Integral Development – AIDER with funding of the
INTERNATIONAL TROPICAL TIMBER ORGANIZATION (ITTO). This project was canalized by the
Peruvian government under the General Forestry and Wildlife Direction, who also facilitated the
management.
The 7 native communities and the NGO Association for Research and Integral Development –
AIDER would be the project proponents.

involve the disturbance of soils after plantation, it will not be necessary to implement this procedure for subsequent verifications.
e. Verify that the lands subject to the activities of the project do not fall in the wetland category;
For each new project instance, the project coordinator will require the landholder to present a certificate of land use and tenancy emitted by the corresponding communal authority that indicates that the land is under agricultural use. As explained in Section 2.2.4, cultivated lands and pastures are not classified as
wetlands. Examples of the format are presented in Annex 19. The land use of each new project instance will be registered in the project database.
f. Confirm that soil disturbance attributable to the project activity does not cover more than 10 per cent of the area in each of the following types of land, when these lands are included within the project boundary:
(v) Land containing organic soils;
Utilizing the procedures and formats described in Annex 11 and previously summarized in Section 1.8.3, UNECAFE’s community technicians will delineate and georeference the area of each new project instance, and the project coordinator will create a polygon in vector and KML formats. The coordinator will
then superimpose the polygon of each instance on the grouped project area’s soil classification layer in Annex 12 in order to identify each instance’s soil type, which will be registered in the project database.
(vi) Land which, in the baseline, is subjected to land-use and management practices and receives inputs listed in appendices 2 and 3 to this methodology.
The coordinator will superimpose the polygon of each new project instance on the grouped project area’s climatic region classification layer in Annex 12 in order to identify the climatic region of each instance, which will be registered in the project database. The coordinator will then repeat the analysis presented
for the initial project instances in Section 2.2.4 to identify in which project instances soil disturbance is restricted.
For the project instances to which the restriction applies, the coordinator will utilize the register of planted trees to confirm that the project instances have received a planting density of less than 6,250 trees per hectare. This limit was calculated considering a planting-hole size of 40 X 40 cm per tree as indicated in
Annex 1, which is equivalent to 0.16 m2 per planted tree (6,250 trees X 0.16 m2 = 1,000 m2, equivalent to 10% of the area of a hectare).
Because the project utilizes a maximum initial density of 600 trees per hectares, this density affords enough room for error that it is not possible for the tree planting activities to generate enough disturbance to reach the 10% threshold. Thus, there will be no monitoring of planting-hole size.
4.2.24 Monitoring of Carbon Stock in Project Trees
4.2.24.1 Methods selected
To estimate carbon stock changes in project trees, the methodological tool AR-TOOL14 indicates that one of the following methods may be selected:
 Method 6.1 “Difference of two independent stock estimations.” This method is recommended when there is a redistribution of the biomass in a stratum, for example as a result of harvesting, or in the case of Coffee CO , due to non-uniform mortality rates on the project areas and the use of liberation thinning. 2
 Method 6.2 “Direct estimation of change by re-measurement of sample plots.” This method is applicable in ex-post estimation of change in carbon stock in trees for monitoring of project activities. This method is efficient when there has been no harvest or disturbance that affects the distribution of biomass and
carbon in the stratum.
In both cases, sample plots are used for the monitoring of carbon in project trees. However, the processes of analysis are distinct. Under method 6.1, different sample plots are established for each monitoring event, and the change in carbon stock in trees is estimated as the difference between two successive and
independent carbon stock estimations.
In contrast, under method 6.2, the accumulation of carbon for each permanent sample plot in each stratum is obtained by subtracting the value of the previous measurement from the value of the new measurement for each sample plot, and afterwards used to calculate the average carbon capture for each stratum and
at the project level. Applying method 6.1 on the permanent sample plots provides the same results as calculating the average of the differences per plot; however, the opposite is not possible. The method described in section 6.2 cannot be used with two independent monitoring events with a different set of sample
plots. This is an important challenge because the use of permanent sample plots for the monitoring of project trees would usually be recommended only if the mortality rates and clearing practices were homogeneous among the different strata of planting configurations. However, it is important to consider that the
continued existence of pre-project trees must also be monitored and that this presents challenges because all pre-project trees cannot be identified and monitored in a cost-effective or practical way. Therefore, the pre-project trees will be monitored within permanent sample plots. Thus, with the objective of reducing
monitoring costs, it is proposed that the carbon stocks of project trees, pre-project trees and shrubs all be monitored using the same permanent plots and thus following method 6.1.

1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The Inner Mongolia Kuduer Improved Forest Management Project (hereafter “the project”) is
located in the central Greater Khingan Mountains of Inner Mongolia, affiliated to Yakeshi City.
The project is implemented by Kuduer Forest Industry Co., LTD, a subsidiary of Inner Mongolia
Forest Industry Group (hereafter “project owner”). The main reasons for implementing the
project include two aspects: on the one hand, in order to play the unique role of forestry in
combating climate change, improve forest structure, enhance forest ecosystem quality and
carbon sink increment, protect biodiversity, promote community development, improve local
ecological environment, and prevent soil erosion and soil desertification; on the other hand,
under the goal of "carbon peaking and carbon neutrality", protecting forests instead of logging
forests can participate in carbon trading and carbon markets, which can increase carbon sink
income, thus improving people's livelihood and realizing regional sustainable development.
Prior to the implementation of the project, the forests in the project area were regarded as
commercial forests and harvested annually according to the timber production plan issued by
the Kuduer Forestry Bureau. From 20/05/2020 of the project implementation, harvesting has
beenstrictlycancelled bytheprojectowner,allowingonlytendingand managing.
The project area is a low to medium mountainous terrain. The geographical coordinates of the
project are 120°52′05″E～122°35′45″E, 49°36′28″N～50°22′10″N, with a forested area of
429,000 ha and a forest coverage rate of 88%. The slope is generally about 15° and the
elevation range is563~1,396 m.The climateiscold-temperate continental monsoon, withlong,
cold winters and short, hot, rainy summers, and wide variations in temperature between day
and night. The annual average temperature is -2.1°C, the average temperature in January is -
27.4°C, theaveragetemperature inJulyis 17.3°C, theannual accumulation temperature above
10°C is 1,508.9°C, and the annual average sunshine hours is 2,775.1 h. The annual
evaporation is 918.4 mm, and the average annual precipitation is 429.2 mm, mainly
concentrated in July and August, accounting for about 50.1% of the total annual precipitation.
The soil is brown coniferous forest soil and gray forest soil. The dominant tree species within
theprojectarea isLarch.
The project has approximately 17,168.96 ha commercial forest, whose ages ranging from
sapling, middle agetomature forest. Beforethe implementation oftheproject, the forest within
the project area was designed and planted as commercial forest, and logged annually
according tothe timber production plan issued byKuduer Forestry Bureau. The implementation
of the project will result in significant carbon sequestration and improve the sustainable
development ofecological system.

Processes to ensure ongoing communication and consultation
The project proponent nominated a specific staff in charge of recording and collecting conflicts
and grievances of local communities and individual farmers. Forest patroller in each project site
plays an important role of treating with ordinary conflicts and grievances. All of the forest
patrollers are coming from local communities whose name and contact number were published
through villager assembly. In case of any conflicts and grievances, stakeholders can either appeal
through village representatives or directly to Ulan Forestry and Grassland Bureau, which is the
most effective ways to solve the problems. They are familiar with the phone numbers of the
project staff or the related contact man, or during community meetings. Moreover, the planting
operations, and tending and management of plantations will avail community labour which will
allow the community villagers to participate in project implementation themselves and find out
or seek for solutions to the conflicts and grievances in the projects.
The project proponent nominated a specific staff in charge of recording and collecting conflicts
and grievances of local communities and individual farmers. Forest patroller in each project site
will play an important role of treating with ordinary conflicts and grievances, and report to the
forest stations or bureau. First, once getting the reports, project proponent and local forest
agency shall contact and discuss with relevant community or other stakeholders within 3 days;
secondly, the specific staff should propose a solution and mediation within a week based on all
collected information from relevant parties; finally, the complications or grievances shall be dealt
within 30 days. For more complicated case which cannot be settled by mediation, the project
proponent shall report to local government, and follow the relevant legal procedure of arbitration
or courts.
All the feedback and grievances received, and the relevant solution shall be recorded and
summarized in the project monitoring report in the next verification, and all the project
documents has been published on Verra website and the website address to download all the
summary project documents has been provided to communities through the public notice boards
in each village.

turbines each with 250 kW capacity. The total installed capacity is 16.35MW. The implementation
of the project was accomplished in November 2003.
For the calculation of the emission reductions of the project the production of one of the three 250
kW turbines has never been considered and also will not be part of the future VCS-QHW-Project.
This turbine was part of a pilot plant, that had been built in 2000, partly financed with a grant
provided by the German Ministry for Economic Development and Cooperation in a so called
Public-Private Partnership Program. Therefore the VCS-project consists of 14 wind turbines with
a capacity of 16.1 MW.
The annual electricity output estimation from 2014 onwards (20,757,555kwh) is calculated as the

emission reductions are 19,034tCO e. 2
